messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 47 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Worst-Case Optimal Covering of Rectangles by Disks

Paper Abstract: Abstract We provide the solution for a fundamental problem of geometric optimization by giving a complete characterization of worst-case optimal disk coverings of rectangles: For any Œª‚â•1ùúÜ1\lambda\geq 1, the critical covering area A‚àó‚Äã(Œª)superscriptùê¥ùúÜA^{*}(\lambda) is the minimum value for which any set of disks with total area at least A‚àó‚Äã(Œª)superscriptùê¥ùúÜA^{*}(\lambda) can cover a rectangle of dimensions Œª√ó1ùúÜ1\lambda\times 1. We show that there is a threshold value Œª2=7/2‚àí1/4‚âà1.035797‚Äã‚Ä¶subscriptùúÜ272141.035797‚Ä¶\lambda_{2}=\sqrt{\sqrt{7}/2-1/4}\approx 1.035797\ldots, such that for Œª<Œª2ùúÜsubscriptùúÜ2\lambda<\lambda_{2} the critical covering area A‚àó‚Äã(Œª)superscriptùê¥ùúÜA^{*}(\lambda) is A‚àó‚Äã(Œª)=3‚ÄãœÄ‚Äã(Œª216+532+9256‚ÄãŒª2)superscriptùê¥ùúÜ3ùúãsuperscriptùúÜ2165329256superscriptùúÜ2A^{*}(\lambda)=3\pi\left(\frac{\lambda^{2}}{16}+\frac{5}{32}+\frac{9}{256\lambda^{2}}\right), and for Œª‚â•Œª2ùúÜsubscriptùúÜ2\lambda\geq\lambda_{2}, the critical area is A‚àó‚Äã(Œª)=œÄ‚Äã(Œª2+2)/4superscriptùê¥ùúÜùúãsuperscriptùúÜ224A^{*}(\lambda)=\pi(\lambda^{2}+2)/4; these values are tight. For the special case Œª=1ùúÜ1\lambda=1, i.e., for covering a unit square, the critical covering area is 195‚ÄãœÄ256‚âà2.39301‚Äã‚Ä¶195ùúã2562.39301‚Ä¶\frac{195\pi}{256}\approx 2.39301\ldots. The proof uses a careful combination of manual and automatic analysis, demonstrating the power of the employed interval arithmetic technique.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 47 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 47"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Multi cover of a polygon minimizing the sum of areas",
        "Covering a line segment with variable radius discs",
        "Minimum-cost coverage of point sets by disks",
        "Optimal circle covering problems and their applications",
        "Packing Geometric Objects with Optimal Worst-Case Density (Multimedia Exposition)",
        "K√∂r√∂k optim√°lis fed√©sei (Optimal covering of circles)",
        "√úber einige optimale Konfigurationen von Kreisen",
        "A constant-factor approximation for multi-covering with disks",
        "Finite packing and covering, volume 154",
        "Density problems for packings and coverings",
        "Covering points by unit disks of fixed location",
        "Cgal, Computational Geometry Algorithms Library",
        "Efficient algorithm for placing a given number of base stations to cover a convex region",
        "Variations of base-station placement problem on the boundary of a convex region",
        "Circle packing for origami design is hard",
        "Rasensprenger zeichnet Kreise auf Fu√üballfeld",
        "Recent progress on packing and covering",
        "Worst-case optimal covering of rectangles by disks",
        "Packing Disks into Disks with Optimal Worst-Case Density",
        "Covering rectangles by disks: The video",
        "Split packing: Algorithms for packing circles with optimal worst-case density",
        "The densest packing of 19 congruent circles in a circle",
        "The densest packing of 12 congruent circles in a circle",
        "The densest packing of 13 congruent circles in a circle",
        "Circles covering squares web page",
        "Packing of 14, 16, 17 and 20 circles in a circle",
        "Dense packings of congruent circles in a circle",
        "Covering a rectangle with equal circles",
        "A survey of solutions for the coverage problems in wireless sensor networks",
        "More is more: the benefits of denser sensor deployment",
        "Curved hexagonal packings of equal disks in a circle",
        "Densest packing of eleven congruent circles in a circle",
        "Loosest circle coverings of an equilateral triangle",
        "Covering a rectangle with six and seven circles",
        "Some packing and covering theorems",
        "Split packing: An algorithm for packing circles with optimal worst-case density",
        "On the solution of numerical functional equations",
        "Conjecturally optimal coverings of an equilateral triangle with up to 36 equal circles",
        "A finite packing problem",
        "Circle covering and its applications for telecommunication networks",
        "Dense packing of equal circles within a circle",
        "An efficient algorithm for optimizing base station site selection to cover a convex square region in cell planning",
        "Packomania",
        "Optimal cover of a disk with three smaller congruent disks",
        "Thinnest covering of a circle by eight, nine, or ten congruent circles",
        "Packing and covering",
        "Minimum-cost sensor coverage of planar regions"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 47 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Worst-Case Optimal Covering of Rectangles by Disks, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
